Zephyrhills Forest Lake Estates Sixth Avenue Water, Sun and Famous Attractions from a Florida Mobile Community There is a reason we refer to Florida as “The Sunshine State.” Miles of sandy beaches, crisp blue skies and endless activity under the sun ensures the nickname fits the bill. Home to famous vacation destinations like Orlando, Florida Keys and Fort Myers, Florida attracts thousands of visitors every year. Explore popular attractions like Disney World and Key West, or get in touch with your adventurous side with some of the best snorkeling and scuba diving in the country. Fine dining, fabulous shopping and world-class golf are other attractions that make Florida the perfect getaway. Search Florida mobile homes and make your next Florida trip an extended stay. ROCKET Sell Your Community ROC Association Donate ROC USA Headquarters 6 Loudon Road, Suite 306 Concord, NH 03301 ROC USA Washington D.C. 1200 G St. NW, Suite 220 Washington, DC 20005 Call 603.513.2791 Email contact_us@rocusa.org Menu Why Resident Ownership? Control sits with the landowners. In traditional manufactured home communities (sometimes still outdatedly called “mobile home parks” or “trailer parks”), even though residents own their homes, the community owners control the land, set the site fees and make the park rules. They also control the condition of the community – including roads, water, electric, waste-water systems and landscaping. Each time the community is sold to a new owner, the rent is likely to increase. English Español Benefits of a ROC? Security, control and zero profit margin. Unlike traditional manufactured home communities, ROCs are not subject to market-based rent increases, and there is no profit margin in monthly site fees. This cooperative ownership gives homeowners the ability to control costs, improve facilities and make their own rules while providing the peace of mind of land ownership. What makes a ROC different? Control Members have a say in their ROC, with major decisions made by democratic vote. An elected Board of Directors appoints committees and hires a property manager to manage daily tasks and oversee the community’s needs. Eviction Security Members continue to own their own homes individually and own an equal share of the land beneath the entire neighborhood. They sign perpetual leases and enjoy lifetime security against unfair eviction. Liability Protection Members are not personally liable for loans made by the cooperative. Their only personal financial investment in the ROC is their Member share, which is typically $250-$500 and paid back when they move out. Strong Sense of Community Homeowners in ROCs get to know their neighbors like never before. They help one another, check in on one another, and get together for potlucks, cleanup days or simply to enjoy their secure neighborhood. Site Fees Compared Use our Site Fee Predictor to see firsthand the savings homeowners in ROCs experience. Each year, ROC USA commissions a market rent study to measure how ROCs are doing relative to the market on the important question of affordability. The data is remarkably consistent: ROCs are not just secure, they’re stable, too. And the affordability in ROCs gets better with time. Our longitudinal study by a national appraisal firm shows ROC Members’ site fees are already 11% below market after just five years, and 21% below market after 10 years. Site Fee Predictor Resident Owned Communities vs. Commercially Owned Communities This tool compares site fee increases in two communities, one a ROC where annual increases average 0.9% and the other a commercially owned community, where annual increases average 7.1%.* Starting Monthly Fee $ Years From Now 5 10 15 20 25 30 $0 Future Monthly Rent Resident Owned $0 Future Monthly Rent Commercially Owned $0 Lifetime Savings For ROC Residents *MHInsider Magazine, May/June 2024 A tale of two communities The journeys to resident ownership in Longmont and Golden, Colo., involved overcoming challenges related to rent increases and unstable living conditions under private ownership. Both communities benefited from the support of nonprofits like ROC USA and Thistle, as well as local government. Longmont’s success hinged on a significant loan from the Longmont City Council and robust community collaboration. In Golden, the community’s purchase involved a larger financial transaction and more direct city involvement. Click below to see what happened in Golden when first a large out-of-state owner took over and then see how things changed when the residents purchased and where they are one-year later. Residents in Golden deal with the aftermath of a private company buying their mobile home park Read the Article How life — and rent — improved when residents took ownership of a Longmont mobile home park Read the Article How does a ROC impact the homeowners who live there? No fear of the community being sold and being forced to move Part of the uncertainty of living in an investor-owned manufactured home community is not knowing if, someday, the community will be sold and homeowners will be forced to move their family and their home. Homeowners in ROCs can live there as long as they choose so long as they pay their site fees and follow the community rules, which are voted on by the Membership. ROC homeowners build more equity in their homes Homes in ROCs are naturally more desirable and sell more quickly than homes in investor-owned communities. Their monthly site fees are lower and, research shows , they have a 12% higher price per square foot when they sell. Resident ownership inspires investments and improvements With the knowledge that their homes – their largest assets – are secure, homeowners increasingly invest in their homes and yards. Beautification committees enhance neighborhood landscaping, boost curb appeal, and improve signage, fostering a more welcoming community and increasing community pride. ROC homeowners connect with their peers near and far The cooperative structure of a ROC fosters an enhanced feeling of community as neighbors come together to help one another and work for the betterment of the entire ROC. They get to know one another like never before and are able to connect with homeowners in ROCs from coast to coast through the ROC Association and ROCKET, ROC USA’s Online Community for Knowledge, Education and Training . We set out to make improvements, and in just the first year finished all the tree work, treated septic systems, upgraded electric panels, and painted speed bumps and fire hydrants. We’re able to pick and choose vendors. We’ve made capital improvements, and saved money in reserves for the future. It’s the best thing we ever did. Kathy Zorotheos Oak Hill Taunton Resident Association Taunton, Mass The reason I’m very happy that we have become to be a ROC is that we’ve become a very close community throughout the process. Plus, we are able to control maintenance and rent. Tom Mikesell Board Treasurer, Meadowood Community Cooperative Littleton, Colo. Your support empowers ROCs and contributes to vital improvement projects. Together, we can build stronger, more vibrant neighborhoods for all residents. Every contribution makes a difference. Join us in making positive change happen! What my friends think I do: Whatever it is, my friends know that I am probably laughing and trying to help someone, which is close enough. Official Bio: Andrea grew up in the Midwest but has lived in nine states. She is married to Jeff and they have two wonderful daughters together named Hannah and Emery. They have lived in Ocala since 2010 and love it! Andrea has had what seems to be a very diverse career, including being a server, nanny, hotel concierge, hotel catering manager, meetings director, account manager, office assistant, and award-winning business owner. While they all were in different industries, all revolved around helping people. She is hoping to bring that same service-minded mentality to her new position at the CEP. Read More Less Louisa Barton Director of Equine Initiative 352.629.8051 x107 Louisa@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Louisa Barton... What my friends think I do: Talk about horses for a living in a British accent and go to all the big horse races and events! Official Bio: Louisa was born in England and lived in Stratford-Upon-Avon, the home of the great Bard, William Shakespeare. She was on a horse before she could walk, competed in England locally in the hunter/jumper horse shows and dabbled in some eventing. She moved to America and rode in a Western saddle for the first time on a Tennessee Walker, and she has been hooked ever since. She now enjoys relaxing trail rides on the beautiful Florida Greenway Trails.  She has been in sales, marketing and communication-related positions most of her life. While recording some radio commercials at a local sports radio station three years ago, she was offered an opportunity to host her own horse radio show right here in ‘the Horse Capital’ and has talked about horses on the radio dial and on the Internet worldwide for a living ever since. Her friends were correct on their thoughts about her!! She loves Marion County and the community we have here and all that we have to offer, so she was delighted to accept the position here at the Chamber and Economic Partnership to help to grow Marion County even more. She takes the most joy out of her children, her horses and helping new businesses to connect with others in this area and her favourite part is meeting new people. Every one of them has a fascinating story. Her specialty is connecting all the people from a great variety of equine disciplines with one another, while also making sure equestrians and non-equestrians connect and begin to understand and appreciate one another. She is thrilled to be a part of this team! Read More Less Chris Blankenship Senior Partner Relations Associate 352.629.8051 x120 Chris@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Chris Blankenship... What my friends think I do: That I work in sales, and that I get paid on the spot after each sale! Official Bio: Chris joined the CEP in December 2022 as Partner Relations Associate, driving new partnerships for the CEP. Chris was born and raised in Savannah, GA and just recently moved to Ocala in June 2022. He graduated from Armstrong State University in 1999 with a BS in Mathematics and Master of Education from Troy University in 2005. From 1999-2008 Chris was a high school Math teacher, Defensive Coordinator for the football team and head Baseball coach. After leaving teaching he got into the health sales industry, pharmaceuticals for 6 years and home health sales for 8 years. In his free time Chris enjoys going to the gym and is a huge sports fan. When not watching sports on TV he travels to Aiken, SC to watch his 2 sons play college baseball. Chris has been married for 4 years to his wife Jamie and they have a blended family of 6. Read More Less Dawn Bowman Director of Downtown Market 352.629.8051 x128 Dawn@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Dawn Bowman... What my friends think I do: Do Facebook live videos and shop. Official Bio: Raised as an Air Force brat, I was not from anywhere. Nov. 2006 in the early hours of dawn, the morning dew was thick, the temperature was cool, horses were galloping in the pastures, the morning was perfect.  We were driving on US 301 where horse farms and Oak Trees lined the road, somewhere between Citra and Anthony. My first visit to Ocala and that was it, I had found my home. Now I can finally say.. “I’m from Ocala” Married to my perfect for me person Matt Cornelison since 1991, we have three wonderful sons, that brought us three amazing daughters-in-law’s that have given us 6 ‘n counting grandchildren. We also have a small petting farm “Finally Home Farm” that we have many rescued fur/feather babies… dogs, cat, chickens, goats, and horses. I am proud to say I have been a part of the CEP since 2012. I started as partner, became an Ambassador, Ambassador Co-chair,  Director of Partner Relations, graduate of LOM class XXVIII, LOM Regent and now Director of Ocala Downtown Market. Prior to the CEP my background includes being a Territory Manager for Nabisco, Owner of B.E.S.Trucking and a Licensed Insurance Agent. Read More Less Arin Conrad Director of Communications & Marketing 352.629.8051 x118 Arin@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Arin Conrad... Official Bio: With a strong background in brand building, strategic marketing, and community outreach, Arin is passionate about helping Ocala grow and thrive. Born and raised in Ocala, Arin has a deep-rooted love for her hometown, which inspires everything she does. She’s held communications roles with the City of Ocala, Marion County Public Schools, and the College of Central Florida—giving her a well-rounded perspective on the area and the people who call it home. Her skills range from video production and graphic design to public engagement, making her a powerful storyteller and advocate for local businesses and initiatives. Arin earned her Bachelor’s degree in Communication from the University of Central Florida. When she’s not working to promote Ocala, you’ll likely find her out and about in the community—volunteering, meeting new people, or discovering some of the city’s hidden gems. Read More Less Kaylin Cornelison Ocala Downtown Market Admistrative Coordinator 352.629.8051 x130 Kaylin@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Kaylin Cornelison... What my friends think I do: Work in public relations and shop at the market every Saturday. Official Bio: Born and raised here in Ocala Kaylin has always felt like this was where she was meant to live. She has always loved being here and never dreamed of leaving her little abode. Most of her family lives in or near here and family is one of the most important parts of her life. After graduating from Forest High School, shoutout to the class of 2011, she went down to Indian River State College for two years to play volleyball at the junior college level. After returning home to Ocala at the end of 2012, she started working at her first job at Publix in Belleview. During that summer of 2013 she started talking to her now husband, Eric. They dated, got engaged, and married all within two years of being together. After getting married in August of 2015, Kaylin moved to Pooler, Georgia since Eric was an active Army soldier stationed there. she was thankfully able to transfer to a Publix store up there and continue to work. Family is very important to them, so living roughly four hours from home was nice as they were able to visit often. In October of 2017, Eric’s new orders took them to Colorado Springs, Colorado. Being over 1,500 miles from home was an adjustment and being there was extremely lonely at times. Now fast forward to now, they are living back home in Ocala with two beautiful little girls that are able to grow up with such a large family that loves them both. Eric is a diesel mechanic at Gary Yeomans Ford in Ocala and until recently Kaylin was in school to become a Medical Coder and Biller. She feels very fortunate for the opportunity to work at the Ocala Downtown Market as an Administrative Coordinator working with two amazing women. Read More Less Tamara Fleischhaker, CCE, IOM, FCCP Interim CEO and Chief eXperience Officer 352.629.8051 x102 Tamara@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Tamara Fleischhaker, CCE, IOM, FCCP... What my friends think I do: Most of them think I work for the government. Always fun to explain how we advocate for business to government. Official Bio: As the CXO for the Ocala Metro Chamber & Economic Partnership, Tamara oversees the programs that help partners acheive the greatest return on their investment. These include advocacy, education, equine initiative, leadership, networking, and partner services. She joined the CEP in April of 2006 with a background in marketing, events, and public policy. Tamara earned her Certified Chamber Executive (CCE) designation, representing only 4% of chamber professionals nationwide. She is also a Florida Certified Chamber Professional (FCCP) and U.S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation Institute for Organization Management (IOM) program graduate. She was the 2016 Professional of the Year for Florida Association of Chamber Professionals (FACP). She was the 2022-23 Chair of the FACP Board of Directors. Tamara’s professional experience includes communications & marketing, brand development, contract management, as well as account management and event production. She also has over 35 years of festival and event management experience with various international festivals and events. She grew up working in her dad's screen printing company, so she is glad to be supporting small business, which is dear to her heart. Read More Less Jessica Gilbert Vice President, Foundation 352.629.8051 x113 Foundation@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Jessica Gilbert... What my friends think I do: I think they are still trying to figure that out – somewhere between having a lot of fun and always being busy. Official Bio: Born and raised in Ocala, Florida, where she attended Forest High School, laying the groundwork for her future endeavors. Fueling her passion for communication and storytelling, she pursued a degree in Communications and Broadcasting at the University of South Florida. Immersed in Florida's vibrant racing community from a young age, Jessica's career trajectory took an exhilarating turn when she joined Turner Broadcasting in Atlanta, contributing her talents to NASCAR's digital team. Despite her success in Atlanta, Jessica's heart remained anchored to her hometown, Ocala. Driven by her dedication to family, she made the pivotal decision to return, prioritizing, Elizabeth and Bradley, and raising them in the familiar embrace of the Ocala community. Jessica's professional journey reflects her diverse skill set, encompassing marketing, brand development, event management, fundraising, and communications. These multifaceted abilities were showcased during her tenure as Director of Community Affairs at Kids Central Inc., where her unwavering commitment to fostering connectivity between the organization and the community flourished over six years. Now, poised for a new chapter, Jessica eagerly embraces the opportunity to merge her love for Ocala/Marion County with her skill set at the CEP. In her free time, you'll find Jessica passionately cheering on players #52 and #28 at the ball fields, or on the water, enveloped in the pages of a book. Read More Less Ron Hipner Partner Relations Associate 352.629.8051 x119 Ron@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Ron Hipner... What my friends think I do: Network 24/7 Official Bio: Ron was born in 1965 in Garden City Michigan, Military family. He was stationed in San Diego 1970. He briefly attended Southwestern College 1984-85.  Ron became a State Contractor in 1990, recognized as an Industry Leader Specializing in Floor and Wall Installations for Clean Rooms, Medical, Pharmaceutical and Manufacturing Facilities. Ron gifted the business to his office staff in 2004 when he moved to Florida. He then became a Real Estate investor 1997 – current. He is Master Captain Certified and the CEO of West Florida Sportfishing 2004-2012. Ron is the owner and operator of a small IT services company from 2008-2010. He was a  Direct Sales Professional and Global Trainer for Enagic USA 2011 to present. Ron is a two time graduate of Rapport Mastery training under Joe Pici of Pici & Pici. 2016,2017. Rons hobbies include and avid fisherman, outdoors enthusiast, playing guitar and enjoys snowboarding. Currently, he is learning Aquaponics and improving his skills at growing food. He also has some Electronics Circuitry Design and Computer Skills both inspired by wanting to know how things work. Read More Less Tom James Director of Executive Engagement 352.629.8051 x117 Tom@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Tom James... What my friends think I do: Smile & shake hands. Schmooze, just like your dad! Sell memberships. Official Bio: Tom James is a born & bred multi-generation Ocala, Florida, Kingdom of the Sun kid, who earned a Bachelors in Communications from UCF. As Director of Executive Engagement, Tom oversees Sponsorship procurement, as well as managing relationships with CEP's Executive Tier partners. Locally, Tom is a long time Elk, a United Way volunteer, and a regular emcee for various community events. Before returning to his hometown in 2012 with his wife Heather, Tom worked as an Account Executive at Sun Broadcasting in Fort Myers/Naples. He spent seven (7) years helping Fox News Radio become the #1 billing station in the Southwest Florida market. Additionally, Tom is a freelance Sportscaster with over 2 decades in the business. A 2-Time Edward R. Murrow Award Winner & former 2-time NBC-TV affiliate Sports Director/Main Anchor, Tom currently does Play-by-Play & Studio Hosting for the ESPN Family of Networks, CBS Sports Network, Lacrosse Sports Network, the Pro Watercross circuit & Florida Gulf Coast University basketball. Locally, he does radio play-by-play for high school football and College of Central Florida basketball and is a regular contributor to the weekly regional Southern Pigskin Tonight college football show. Read More Less Erin A. Jones Director of Healthcare Development 352.629.8051 x111 Erin@OcalaCEP.com Read More about Erin A. Jones... What my friends think I do: Go to lunches and posting said lunches on social media and attend events… they aren’t wrong! Official Bio: Erin is the Director of Healthcare Development, a newly developed position for the CEP. Erin started her healthcare journey with CVS Pharmacy as a Cpht and Pharmacy Recruiter/Intern Program Manager. Enjoy lovely lake views and modern amenities from all areas of our facility. The Lakeshore Center features banquet seating for more than 200 people, a modern catering kitchen, additional rooms for use and a state of the art audio-visual system. The historic Withers-Maguire House is suited for bridal party preparations and smaller meetings and events. For more information contact the Parks and Leisure Services Administrative office at 407-877-5803. Facilities The Parks and Leisure Services Department manages six recreation centers located throughout the city. A variety of programs for youth, adults and seniors are offered at these centers throughout the week. All centers are available during weekday evenings and on weekends to rent for family gatherings, parties, meetings, receptions, banquets and other special occasions. For more information contact the Parks and Leisure Services Administrative office at 407-877-5803. Parks The Parks and Leisure Services Department operates and maintains thirteen parks throughout the city with some of the following amenities: picnic areas, playgrounds, basketball and tennis courts, baseball, softball, football and soccer fields, and pavilions. Discover a park close to you. Programs The Parks and Leisure Services Department provides a variety of year-round recreational programs and events for youth , adults and seniors to enhance the quality of life for the residents of Ocoee. For more information on the programs and classes, please contact the Jim Beech Recreation Center at 407-905-3180 or check out our Facebook Page . Family Aquatic Center The Ocoee Family Aquatic Center provides a safe and relaxing setting for families to enjoy their day. Special features include a zero depth entry for easy access and spray features for the kids to splash the day away. For more information on programs and classes at the aquatic center, contact the Jim Beech Recreation Center at 407-905-3180. Ocoee Music Festival The City of Ocoee’s Fall Music Festival is celebrated annually drawing more than 20,000 people each year. The festival includes both local and national entertainment and one of the best fireworks displays in Central Florida. It is non-stop fun! For more information please contact Mark Johnson , Parks & Leisure Services Director or check the Festival website .
